title: shortDescription
content: Thin-slice CT typically for detailed lung imaging.

title: NIfTI to DICOM
content: Ensure the NIFTI image is high quality and properly aligned to the region of interest.
Add patient, study, and image metadata (e.g., PatientName, PatientID, Modality).
Use tools like dcm2niix (in reverse) or write a custom script to convert NIFTI to DICOM.
Verify the DICOM file’s integrity, metadata, and compatibility with PACS.
Upload the DICOM file to your medical imaging system for clinical use.

title: TIFF to DICOM
content: Ensure the TIFF image is high quality and properly cropped to the region of interest.
Add patient, study, and image metadata (e.g., PatientName, PatientID, Modality).
Use tools like img2dcm or write a custom script to convert TIFF to DICOM.
Verify the DICOM file’s integrity, metadata, and compatibility with PACS.
Upload the DICOM file to your medical imaging system for clinical use.

title: Imaging Principle
content: X-ray-based tomography optimized for high spatial resolution through thin-slice acquisition (0.5–1.5 mm), high kVp/mAs settings, and high-frequency reconstruction kernels. It targets high-contrast anatomy (e.g., lungs) using axial or helical scanning, producing detailed 3D grayscale volumes without reliance on contrast agents.

title: HDR/IMG to DICOM
content: Ensure the HDR/IMG files are high quality and properly aligned to the region of interest.
Add patient, study, and image metadata (e.g., PatientName, PatientID, Modality, Slice Thickness).
Use tools like ITK-SNAP or write a custom script to convert HDR/IMG to DICOM.
Verify the DICOM file’s integrity and metadata, and compatibility with PACS.
Upload the DICOM file to your medical imaging system for clinical use.

title: Data Type
content: "16-bit Grayscale (Hounsfield Units) "	Floating-Point Data	8-bit Grayscale	3D Volumetric	"Time-Series "	"Functional Imaging "

title: Voxel Size / Pixel Spacing
content: "Pixel spacing ~0.3 mm to 0.6 mm/ Voxel size ~0.3 x0.3 x0.5 mm to 0.6 x0.6 x1 mm "

title: Equipment Used
content: CT Scanner: A multi-detector CT (MDCT) scanner with thin-slice imaging capabilities (typically submillimeter slices).	High-Resolution Reconstruction Algorithms: To enhance fine detail and reduce noise.	High-Powered X-ray Tube: To support high-resolution imaging.	Workstation: For advanced image analysis and post-processing (e.g., MPR, MIP).	Lung Imaging Protocols: Tailored for high-resolution imaging of the lungs.

title: Typical Manufacturers
content: Siemens Healthineers	GE Healthcare	Hitachi Healthcare	Canon Medical Systems

title: Primary Uses
content: "Interstitial Lung Disease (ILD) "	COPD	Bronchiectasis	Pulmonary Infections	lung cancers

title: Specialized Uses
content: Quantitative Lung Analysis	Lung Transplant Evaluation	"Pre-Operative Planning "	Radiation Therapy Planning	Pediatric Lung Imaging

title: Safety Concerns
content: "Radiation Exposure Cumulative Radiation Dose        "	"Pediatric pregnant Patients"	"Contrast-Induced Nephropathy (CIN) allergy to contrast"	Claustrophobia and Anxiety	Artifacts and Misdiagnosis

title: Common Preprocessing Steps
content: Noise Reduction	Image Reconstruction	Artifact Correction	Contrast Adjustment	Segmentation	"Resampling and Normalization "

title: Compression Methods (if any)
content: "Lossless Compression: Run-Length  Encoding (RLE): Compresses consecutive identical values (e.g., large areas of air in lung images) Lempel-Ziv-Welch (LZW): A dictionary-based method used in formats like TIFF or GIF ZIP/FLATE: Commonly used in DICOM files to compress data without loss"	"Lossy Compression:JPEG: Uses discrete cosine transform (DCT) to compress images, often applied to 2D slices of HRCT JPEG 2000: An advanced wavelet-based method offering better quality at higher compression ratios; supports both lossy and lossless modes MPEG: For dynamic HRCT (e.g., 4D imaging), though rare in static HRCT scans"	"Wavelet-Based Compression: Embedded in JPEG 2000 or custom medical imaging algorithms Progressive encoding allows reconstruction at different quality levels"	"DICOM Compression: Lossless JPEG: Embedded in DICOM for non-destructive compression JPEG-LS: A near-lossless method with better compression than traditional lossless JPEG JPEG 2000: Increasingly supported in modern DICOM systems"	"Region-of-Interest (ROI) Compression: Wavelet-based ROI coding (e.g., in JPEG 2000) Custom algorithms in research identify lung fields first via segmentation"

title: Technical Challenges
content: "Radiation Dose:  Higher doses raise concerns, especially for repeated scans (e.g., monitoring chronic lung diseases like fibrosis)"	"Image Noise:  Noise can mimic or mask pathological patterns, complicating diagnosis"	"Motion Artifacts: Artifacts like streaking or double contours can reduce diagnostic accuracy"	"Partial Volume Effects: Can obscure subtle abnormalities like micronodules or early emphysema"	"Data Volume and Storage: Slows workflows in Picture Archiving and Communication Systems (PACS) and increases costs"	"Reconstruction Artifacts: May mimic pathology (e.g., artificial thickening of bronchial walls)"

title: Clinical Limitations
content: Limited Soft Tissue Contrast	Inability to Assess Dynamic Processes	Radiation Exposure	Interobserver Variability	False Positives and Mimics	Limited Sensitivity for Early Disease
